@CNevd I have found the reason. If using metric, it will wait for the data processed by GPU and then start a new iteration. But if not using metric, it will keep loading data whether GPU finishes processing data or not. So the previous data would not be freed.
Thank you very much, I will close the issue.

I managed to compile amalgamation, my step : 
```
# make standalone toolchain for android
android-ndk-r15/build/tools/make_standalone_toolchain.py --arch arm  --api 21 --install-dir android_compiler_armv7_32bit --stl=libc++ --force
export PATH=/home/user/Documents/lib/android_compiler_armv7_32bit/bin/:$PATH
# OpenBLAS
cd $PATH_TO_OPENBLAS
make TARGET=ARMV7 HOSTCC=gcc CC=arm-linux-androideabi-gcc NOFORTRAN=1 libs
# mxnet amalgamation
cd $PATH_TO_MXNET/amalgamation
# edit Makefile to add OpenBLAS Path
make mxnet_predict-all.cc
export CC=arm-linux-androideabi-clang
export CXX=arm-linux-androideabi-clang++
# fopen64 is not known, I replace them by std::fopen in mxnet_predict-all.cc
make ANDROID=1
```

To do in this order or it will not work. 
`make mxnet_predict-all.cc` don't work correctly after `export CC=...` and `export CXX=...`

This would totally be possible by keeping a list of references to val instead of val.handle. However this would lead to mx.nd.save to slice up the rows and mx.nd.load to return a list of slices instead of a single matrix:

```
In [1]: import mxnet as mx

In [2]: d = mx.nd.zeros((2,10))

In [3]: mx.nd.save("testndarray", d)

In [4]: e
Out[4]: [<NDArray 10 @cpu(0)>, <NDArray 10 @cpu(0)>]
```
So while possible I think the idea of mx.nd.load returning something other than what was passed in in mx.nd.save, seems like the wrong behavior.

I don't have any problems executing above code with a current version of mxnet. ~~@piiswrong do you have any insight into why it is working now compared to earlier this year? @tornadomeet do you still experience this issue? Perhaps it is related to a different cuda version/system configuration..~~ https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4695 seems to contain the fix.


In general I believe [using python multiprocessing and specifying the forkserver start method](https://docs.python.org/3/library/multiprocessing.html#contexts-and-start-methods) before importing mxnet should be a workaround for any cuda related multiprocessing issues. In particular it should still allow creating new processes after mxnet was imported, as the processes are forked from the forkserver which has no cuda context. This also seems to be [what pytorch is doing](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/334#issuecomment-268407605).

No, I meant when you do `mx.nd.save('a', mx.nd.zeros((100,)))`, save will detect that mx.nd.zeros((100,)) is an array instead of a list and save [mx.nd.zeros((100,))] instead. The returned value would be a list of 1 ndarray

I guess you installed R using brew. There is one key difference between brew and official R.

The R installed from brew will try to install the package from source by default. The R from R project website will try the pre-built pkg first.

Please try 

```r
install.packages("mxnet", type = "mac.binary")
```

@Mrugankakarte 

I just modified your code a little: (1) remove the "id" column; (2) normalization the `train.y`.

Although not a good result, at least not all the same.

```r
library(caret)
library(mxnet)

#Reading the cleaned data
train <- read.csv("transformed train.csv")
test <- read.csv("transformed test.csv")
test1 <- data.matrix(test[, -2])

#Dividing training data into train and validation
ind <- createDataPartition(train$SalePrice, p = 0.6, list = F)
train.x <- data.matrix(train[ind, c(-1,-2)])
train.y <- train[ind, 2]
train.y <- (train.y - 34000) / (760000 - 34000)
valid.x <- data.matrix(train[-ind, c(-1,-2)])
valid.y <- train[-ind, 2]
valid.y <- (valid.y - 34000) / (760000 - 34000)

mx.set.seed(42)
model <- mx.mlp(data = train.x,
                label = train.y,
                hidden_node = 20,
                out_node = 1,
                num.round = 50,
                learning.rate = 1e-6,
                momentum = 0.9,
                eval.metric = mx.metric.rmse,
                out_activation = "rmse")

preds <- predict(model, valid.x)

preds <- preds * (760000 - 34000) + 34000

head(preds[1, ])
## [1] 36875.11 36565.02 35717.43 36714.63 36972.66 38572.08
```

@GuilongZh Please try the code below. I think `1.639859e-05` is acceptable.

```r
library(mxnet)

data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")

train.ind <- seq(1, 506, 3)
train.x <- data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
train.y <- BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
test.x <- data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
test.y <- BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]

data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden = 20, name = "fc1")
act1 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc1, act_type = "relu", name = "relu1")
fc2 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act1, num_hidden = 1, name = "fc2")
mlp <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc2, name = "mlp")

mx.set.seed(0)
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(mlp, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                                     ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
                                     learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse)

preds <- predict(model, train.x)

dim(model$arg.params$fc1_weight)
dim(model$arg.params$fc1_bias)
dim(model$arg.params$fc2_weight)
dim(model$arg.params$fc2_bias)

W1 <- as.array(model$arg.params$fc1_weight)
b1 <- as.array(model$arg.params$fc1_bias)
W2 <- as.array(model$arg.params$fc2_weight)
b2 <- as.array(model$arg.params$fc2_bias)

data <- as.matrix(train.x)
pred <- data %*% W1
for (i in length(b1)) {
  pred[, i] <- pred[, i] + b1[i]
}

pred = matrix(pmax(0, pred), nrow = nrow(pred))

pred <- pred %*% W2
for (i in length(b2)) {
  pred[, i] <- pred[, i] + b2[i]
}

sum((pred - t(preds))^2)
# [1] 1.639859e-05
```

I figured that I can read the .lst file to find out the labels. 
However I am still curious to find out how to access the data content in Rec file.

Please try the code below. I used the cifar10 data from http://data.mxnet.io/mxnet/data/cifar10.zip

```r
dataiter <- mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
  path.imgrec     = "./data/cifar/train.rec",
  path.imglist    = "./data/cifar/train.lst",
  mean.img        = "./data/cifar/cifar10_mean.bin",
  batch.size      = 100,
  data.shape      = c(28, 28, 3),
  rand.crop       = TRUE,
  rand.mirror     = TRUE
)

dataiter$reset()

dataiter$iter.next()

dataiter$value()$label

dataiter$value()$data
```
You can get more info on how to use iterators from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/tests/testthat/test_io.R

As far as I can read from the C code, all batches are initialized with 0s: `batch.resize(batch_size * line_size, 0.0f)`. 
Then, only existing data is overwritten: `size_t end = std::min(order.size(), begin + batch_size);`.
 Therefore, I would assume that incomplete batches are padded by 0. However, testing the behaviour in R reveals that the data from the previous batch is repeated if a batch is incomplete:

```
library(mxnet)

## check what an iterator does with non-complete batches
dat <- matrix(1:10, nrow = 1)

test <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = dat, label = dat, batch.size = 3, shuffle = FALSE)

test$reset()
nbatch <- 1
while(test$iter.next()){
  cat("batch: ", nbatch, "\n")
  print(as.array(test$value()$data))
  nbatch <- nbatch + 1
}

##     [,1] [,2] [,3]

##batch:  4 
##     [,1] [,2] [,3]
##[1,]   10    8    9
```
